choices.A: Files are scanned for viruses before they are allowed to run.
choices.D: Attacks can be mitigated before the application connection occurs.

discussion.content: D. Because Umbrella can stop connections to malicious domains that could infect/compromise the host connecting to it via its features.

questions.question_text: What is a benefit of using Cisco Umbrella?

Client workstations are experiencing extremely poor response time. An engineer suspects that an attacker is eavesdropping and making independent connections while relaying messages between victims to make them think they are talking to each other over a private connection. Which feature must be enabled and configured to provide relief from this type of attack?

discussion.content:
Given example is perfect fit to use Dynamic ARP Inspection. 
D is correct answer
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/lan/catalyst4500/12-2/25ew/configuration/guide/conf/dynarp.html

Selected Answer: D
The question describes a type of a man in the middle attack that would typically involve arp poisoning and can be prevented by DIA.

Selected Answer: D
As "to make them think they are talking to each other over a private connection" So, they need to communicate each others. So, Private VLAN is incorrect.
D. Dynamic ARP Inspection

Selected Answer: D
The reason I would go for the D, Because in the question "Which feature must be enabled and configured to provide "relief" from this type of attack?" In my understanding this means you have to take an action immediately. So I would go for D

Selected Answer: D
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/lan/catalyst4500/12-2/25ew/configuration/guide/conf/dynarp.html

Selected Answer: C
PRIVATE VLAN, isolated pvlan, so the hosts in same subnet can not talk each other.

comments.content: And why do you think, that they don't want to talk to each other?

discussion.content:
hostname (config)# access-list flow_export_acl permit ip host 209.165.200.224 host 209.165.201.224
hostname (config)# class-map flow_export_class
hostname (config-cmap)# match access-list flow_export_acl
hostname (config)# policy-map flow_export_policy
hostname (config-pmap)# class flow_export_class
hostname (config-pmap-c)# flow-export event-type all destination 209.165.200.230
hostname (config-pmap)# class class-default
hostname (config-pmap-c)# flow-export event-type all destination 209.165.201.29
hostname (config)# service-policy flow_export_policy global

Answer: A
CiscoASA(config-pmap-c)# flow-export event-type all destination 209.165.201.10

questions.question_text: Which command is used to log all events to a destination collector 209.165.201.10?
An engineer is configuring IPsec VPN and needs an authentication protocol that is reliable and supports ACK and sequence. Which protocol accomplishes this goal?

discussion.content: Answer 'C' : https://www.hypr.com/security-encyclopedia/encapsulating-security-payload-esp

Selected Answer: C
Ikev1 does not have acks, ikev2 does:
https://learningnetwork.cisco.com/s/article/comparison-between-ikev1-and-ikev2

Selected Answer: C
ESP - it has ACK & sequence numbers, not IKEv1
But call it authentication protocol is misleading. Shame on you, Cisco

Selected Answer: C
Has to be IKEv2 (ack is there) and ESP - so C

Selected Answer: B
ESP provides confidentiality, authentication, and integrity to IP Packets. It does NOT include mechanisms for acknowledging or sequencing messages - which is a requirement for this question. IKEv1 SUPPORTS acknowledgements and sequencing to ensure reliable delivery of messages during the negotiation process.

comments.content: Neither IKEv1 or ESP has ACK messages. IKEv1 has 6 messages, to negotiate tunnel, that's all. ESP sure does have sequence numbers.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc7402.html

Selected Answer: B
Ikev1 does authentication and a has a handshake process https://www.cisco.com/c/es_mx/support/docs/security-vpn/ipsec-negotiation-ike-protocols/217432-understand-ipsec-ikev1-protocol.html
A,C and D are Encryption protocols... so B
it is B ikev1

choices.A: The server changed its time source to stratum 1.
choices.C: NTP authentication has been configured on the network device.
choices.B: The network device is sending the wrong password to the server.
choices.D: NTP authentication has been configured on the NTP server.

questions.question_text: An administrator is testing new configuration on a network device. The network device had a previously established association with the NTP server but is no longer processing time updates. What is the cause of this issue?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
The new configuration was done on the network device, so whatever caused the loss of communication happened on the client, that left us with B and C. What was done on the network device was a new configuration not modification of existing configuration. B means the server and network device would have had a password configured and it was modified on the device but since it is a new setting, that leaves us with option C. This means NTP authentication was configured on the device but yet to be implemented on the server

Selected Answer: C
In my opinion, new configuration means, some new feature has been configured, which in this case is authentication. That's why NTP ain't working. If "auth" was already configured then - we can't say "entering the wrong password" would qualify as a new configuration. 

It is a very tricky question, with not a lot of details.

comments.content: Configuration change not password change and it is happening in network device and no where it mentioned that authentication was configured earlier..

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Correct answer should be B, not D because the configuration was not done in the NTP server and not C because the network device had a previously established association with the NTP server before testing the new configuration which means NTP authentication was already configured before so the only thing that could have cause this is if he changed the password on the network device

Correct answer should be B, not D because the configuration was not done in the NTP server and not C because the network device had a previously established association with the NTP server before testing the new configuration which means NTP authentication was already configured before so the only thing that could have cause this is if he changed the password on the network device
Sorry missed out reading "new configuration" being tested on the network device....Ans should be C in that case...

I think it should be D. NTP authentication added on the server must be the cause for the update no longer happening on the given network device, assuming there was no change on the network device (that's how the question seems to be framed).

comments.content: Makes sense.. The situation must be that there were no authentication required previously (hence it worked)- but now it is required due to change on the NTP server side
